Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Biocatalysis Development using High-throughput Droplet Microfluidics and Mass Spectrometry

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1604087
Kennedy, Robert T.

The goal of this project is to develop a new approach to facilitate the development of faster, greener, and cheaper ways of synthesizing drugs. The challenge in using enzymes is that natural occurring enzymes do not often catalyze the exact reaction that is needed for a pharmaceutical development project. The goal in this project is to develop a high-throughput, highly miniaturized method of engineering enzymes to perform desired reactions. It is anticipated that this technology can be used to develop such biocatalysts in a few days for any desired chemical transformation. This capability could greatly facilitate drug development projects by making available tailor-made catalysts for any reaction in a time and cost-effective manner.

Enzyme engineering for pharmaceutical process chemistry and manufacturing has become a revolutionary technology as enzymatic transformations potentially offer high yield, selectivity and enantiomeric purity with low cost and green chemistry. The team proposes development of a novel screening system to reduce the material use, eliminate special reagents and improve the overall throughput in enzyme engineering and screening. The three key modules include (i) cell-free protein synthesis (CFPS), (ii) droplet microfluidics and (iii) mass spectrometry (MS). CFPS offers the potential speed advantage as it bypasses the cell growth and protein harvest steps. It can be completed with shorter cycle time, produces purer proteins, and at the same time allows active monitoring, direct manipulation, and rapid sampling. Droplet microfluidics offers a platform for performing reactions and assays in nanoliter or less volume which is also adaptive to be automated. MS allows the possibility for fast development of label-free assays for a wide variety of potential substrates with minimal delay. The proposed approach is transformative because it will allow virtually any enzymatic transformation to be engineered in 10-fold less time by eliminating the need to develop labels, coupled reactions, or using cells in the process. The proposed technology will be useful also for other applications in chemical process development.
This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the GOALI Program of the Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we sought to develop a miniaturized system that enabled the rapid development of enzymes engineered to catalyze specific reactions. Catalysts are vital to economy as they are used to make feasible chemical reactions for industrial purposes. Enzymes are an attractive class of catalysts because they are greener and more selective than traditional small molecule catalysts. Since most enzymes do not catalyze reactions that are useful in industry, a route to creating useful enzymes is needed.  Enzyme engineering is a technology for creating proteins that can catalyze reactions of interest. Enzyme engineering involves creating thousands of variants of an enzyme and testing them to see if any are an improvement over the original enzymes. Resulting improved enzymes can be selected and further mutated and tested. Following this process allows the evolution of enzymes for catalysis. This process was recognized with a Nobel Prize in 2018 and is starting to have an impact in industry. A bottleneck in using this approach is the long time required to create and test each enzyme variant. Droplet microfluidics is a technology that has shown promise for enabling high-throughput enzyme engineering. In this technology, individual samples of picoliter to nanoliter volume are compartmentalized as droplets within an immiscible carrier fluid. Microfabrication enables creation of conduits for manipulating these samples at high throughput. Although some success has previously been found in using droplet microfluidics for enzyme engineering, it was limited by using fluorescence to detect reaction products. Since most reactions do not produce fluorescence, it is highly limited. In this project we successfully developed a droplet microfluidic system that allowed reactions to be screened based on the mass change associated with reactions, i.e. we used mass spectrometry as the readout. We developed all of the microfluidic tools to allow individual enzyme variants to be stored, expressed, and incubated to reaction within nanoliter droplets. Further, we developed a method to split the droplets so that one portion could be analyzed by mass spectrometry and then other half collected or sent to waste depending on the signals obtained by mass spectrometry. We further demonstrated that we could select active enzyme variants from less active ones. The system is 50x faster, 300x cheaper, and requires half the personnel to perform compared to the standard techniques used in industry. We expect that with further development this method will be useful for meeting the demand of industry for biocatalysts. In addition to scientific work, we trained 3 students in advanced microfluidics, mass spectrometry, and enzyme engineering in the course of this project. These students also worked closely with industrial collaborators, even working on site at Merck, to gain experience in industrial research.
